newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish debt/currency market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Swedish debt/currency market closing report.

text.p: Swedish debt yields weakened and the crown lost ground against the mark on worries about EMU both domestically and internationally.
"We traded on our own merits this morning, then we just followed the German market," one dealer said.

Swedish radio news said Prime Minister Goran Persson and Finance Minister Erik Asbrink had agreed the country should not join EMU in the next parliamentary term 1998-2002 unless new general elections were held. Analysts said this could mean a delay in Swedish EMU membership until 2003.
Some market players and politicians said the radio report could be correct, but said a severe market reaction was unlikely.
International EMU worries spread to Sweden and the Riksbank bought crowns at around 4.52 against the mark, dealers said.

The crown slid to 4.5210 against the mark from 4.4920 late on Tuesday. Six-month T-bill rates increased four basis points to 4.30 percent and the ten year bond yields rose seven basis points to 7.11 percent.
